prompt: Write a poem about underpass echo in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
"Galimaul's Grotto of Gobbling Sound"

Beware the frumious underpass' might,
Where echos form a ghostly band,
Guttural growls of Glimmerwings take flight,
As Galimaul's eerie whispers expand.

Prepare thyself with valiant heart and ear,
To face the Gobbling wight of sound's dark lair,
The Slamurfangs of reverberation clear,
And sharpen thy wit with stealthy, stalwart air.

Thy faithful Rhubarbrow lies in wait,
For MawkErups with earsforeleaning bent,
Ready to pounce upon the Grotto's gate,
With piercing Spoing and gleeful, vict'rous rent.

In signal triumph, up thou emergest bright,
Fraywhelks both the beast of Gobbling might,
Echoes routed, awaiting chainèd night,
Galimaul's confusion puts tongues at light.

Now from the underpass thou emergest sound,
A hero of wordhacks and wonder woo'd,
Gather round thee bowlites lift wine's capacity round,
Recalling the growls of guttural potency unbound...

Yet beware the frumious underpass' might...
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title is present before first stanza: "Galimaul's Grotto of Gobbling Sound".</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 5 stanzas total; line counts per stanza: 4,4,4,4,4; all are quatrains; so ≥70% quatrains and stanza count in 3–8 range -> yes.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Alternating longer/shorter lines: The pattern is roughly consistent with longer/shorter lines alternating in syllable counts; most stanzas show a difference in content word counts between odd and even lines though less distinct than Jabberwocky but still present in ≥60% of stanzas -> yes.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme (lines 2,4): Mostly slant rhymes or clear rhymes in each stanza (e.g., "band"/"expand", "clear"/"air", "bent"/"rent", "might"/"light"); no excessive AABB dominance; pattern consistent in ≥60% stanzas -> yes.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza has ring echo: repeats "beware the frumious underpass' might" phrase, echoing beginning lines with ≥2 repeated content words/phrases and a clear refrain setup -> yes.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition: First stanza starts with "Beware the frumious underpass' might", a direct warning to the protagonist -> yes.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation before encounter: Second stanza shows protagonist prepares with "Prepare thyself with valiant heart and ear", "sharpen thy wit", "stealthy, stalwart air" -> yes.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter/confrontation: Third stanza mentions "Ready to pounce upon the Grotto's gate", naming adversaries like "MawkErups", implies a direct encounter -> yes.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive action: Fourth stanza describes triumph and driving out ("Fraywhelks both the beast", "Echoes routed"), showing decisive resolution -> yes.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration: Final stanza depicts emerging sound as hero and gathering with "bowlites lift wine's capacity," signifying celebration acknowledging success -> yes.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Coinages: Distinct invented words include Galimaul, Gobbling, Glimmerwings, Slamurfangs, Rhubarbrow, MawkErups, earsforeleaning, Spoing, vict'rous rent, Fraywhelks, bowlites, wordhacks, wonder woo'd. At least 8 distinct novel coinages -> yes.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza has at least one coinage: 1st (Galimaul, Gobbling, Glimmerwings), 2nd (Slamurfangs), 3rd (Rhubarbrow, MawkErups, Spoing), 4th (Fraywhelks), 5th (bowlites, wordhacks, wonder woo'd) -> yes.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Named non-canonical creatures/entities present other than Jabberwock: Galimaul, Glimmerwings, Slamurfangs, Rhubarbrow, MawkErups, Fraywhelks, bowlites (some ambiguous but mostly creatures or entities in context) -> yes.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia bursts: "Spoing" stands out as onomatopoeia; "rent" might be more abstract; no strong evidence of ≥2 distinct onomatopoeic bursts like "snicker-snack" or "burble"; only one clear onomatopoeia -> no.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance: Clear within-line alliteration/consonance in at least two stanzas: e.g. stanza 1 ("Guttural growls of Glimmerwings"), stanza 2 ("sharpen thy wit with stealthy, stalwart air"), stanza 3 ("piercing Spoing and gleeful, vict'rous rent") -> yes.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Tone is whimsical and mythic with archaic/traditional diction and invented words, consistent with Jabberwocky style -> yes.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No lines verbatim from canonical Jabberwocky poem are repeated; wording and phrasing are original -> yes.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens minimal or absent except "frumious"; overall canonical usage ≤8 tokens -> yes.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable pattern: longest lines roughly 8–9 syllables; shorter lines ~5–7; alternating pattern consistent in ≥60% stanzas -> yes.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety: (2,4) end rhymes like "band"/"expand", "clear"/"air", "bent"/"rent", "might"/"light", "round"/"unbound"; no exact end word repeated more than twice outside ring phrase; variety of rhymes maintained -> yes.</C20_think>
<C21_think>Lexical repetition: No content word is overused excessively; coinages and common words well balanced; no >5 times or >8% overuse -> yes.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinage variety: Coinages come from distinct roots: e.g. Galimaul, Glimmerwings, Slamurfangs, Rhubarbrow, MawkErups, Spoing, Fraywhelks, bowlites, wordhacks; more than four distinct roots; no suffix dominates -> yes.</C22_think>

prompt: Write a poem about morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
"Misty Morn's Fearsome Foe"

'Twas brillig and the sloths did gyre
In ulfur woods, where vapors cling
Amidst the mizzle, fears conspire
As Glibblejaws, with wailing ring

Beware the Flish, my son, I pray
With snickering blade and eyes aglow
Thy gromble-spear in readiness array
To vanquish fog's fell wraiths that grow

He took the vorxle path, so steep
The Flish lunged forth, with mewling shout
The foghorn's blast, a deafening creep
K'takk! The Glibblejaws did rout

With galimatias in the morning air
He strode, triumphant, back to town
The burble of joy, the people share
As mizzle clears, the sun's warm crown

'Tis brillig, now the sloths do spin
In ulfur woods, where vapors cling
Amidst the mizzle, tales begin
Of Glibblejaws, and Flish's sting
label: high
judge_raw:

No strict AABB dominance; mostly ABAB or similar pattern (some internal rhyme, slant rhyme). Meeting threshold likely.</C4_think>

<C6_think>Early admonition is present: stanza 2 starts with "Beware the Flish, my son, I pray," which is clearly a warning to protagonist.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation is indicated with "Thy gromble-spear in readiness array"—the protagonist readies a tool before encounter.</C7_think>

prompt: Write a poem about déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
**Frabjul Déjà**

Beware the Déjàvu, my son!
In mystic mists, it doth begin
With whispered warnings, faint and undone,
As Whifllepox, the wispy wind, doth spin.

'Tis prep'd to pounce, with wily guile
Thy mind aflame, in flumplenooks of fire
Gather 'round, thy gallant trials pile
When Flishyblop, the fierce foreboder, doth conspire.

With "Zinga-zanga!" cry, it doth appear
Thy heart aflap, like Fimbulfly's wings in air
In twisted turmoil, the Déjàvu draws near
When Wizzlethorpe, the wraith, thy senses doth ensnare.

Yet, armed with valor, thou dost take the stage
With "Flap-flumplen!" cry, the Déjàvu dost slay
When Flishyblop, in fawning fealty, doth engage
Thy triumph sung, by Whifllepox, in wispy sway.

Thy legend told, in verse and jubilant cheer
With Déjàvu, laid low, thou dost return, my dear
The mystic mists, where wisps of Whifllepox appear
Beware the Déjàvu, my son!
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "**Frabjul Déjà**" is present and separate before first stanza.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 6 stanzas total; all are quatrains (4 lines each), so 100% quatrains and stanza count within 3–8 range.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Lines alternate longer/shorter meter in most stanzas with a noticeable difference in content-word count and syllable length (e.g., lines 1,3 longer; 2,4 shorter), meeting ≈8/6 pattern in majority.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Most stanzas rhyme in lines (2,4) with some slant rhymes; rhyme pattern usually ABXB (with B rhymes on lines 2,4). No dominant AABB pattern observed.</C4_think>
<C5_think>The final stanza repeats content words and phrases from the opening stanza notably ("Beware the Déjàvu, my son!", Whifllepox), functioning as a ring/compositional echo.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition present — first stanza is a warning "Beware the Déjàvu, my son!"</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation indicated in stanza 2, with protagonist gathering courage, trials, and readiness to face threat.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Clear encounter occurs in stanza 3, describing arrival and menace of Déjàvu and creatures like Wizzlethorpe.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive slaying action conveyed in stanza 4 with cry and defeat of Déjàvu.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration appear in stanza 5 and 6 — triumphant telling of legend, jubilant cheer, return, and echo of original warning.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Distinct coined or invented words: Frabjul, Whifllepox, flumplenooks, Flishyblop, Zinga-zanga, Fimbulfly, Wizzlethorpe, Flap-flumplen (8 distinct coinages).</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least one distinct coinage; coinages are well spread.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Multiple named entities: Whifllepox, Flishyblop, Fimbulfly, Wizzlethorpe, all non-canonical creatures or entities associated with Déjàvu effects; central to action.</C13_think>
<C14_think>At least two onomatopoeic bursts: "Zinga-zanga!", "Flap-flumplen!" indicating sounds or cries; these fit the onomatopoeia criterion.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration and consonance clear in stanzas 2 ("flumplenooks of fire," "gallant... trials pile") and 4 ("fawning fealty," "Flishyblop"), others have mild but noticeable patterns.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Tonal quality is whimsical and mythic, evoking mysterious mystical atmosphere and legendary feel, no flat prose or promotional tone.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No exact verbatim lines from canonical 'Jabberwocky'; all lines original though referencing similar themes and coinages style.</C17_think>

<C19_think>Syllable counts in most stanzas fit the Jabberwocky pattern (lines about 8–9 syllables vs 5–7 syllables alternating), ≥60% compliant.</C19_think>

<C21_think>No overuse of single content words outside ring repetition; vocabulary is varied, no content word repeated excessively.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages show at least 5+ distinct roots (flumplen-, Whifllep-, Flishy-, Fimbul-, Wizzle-, Zinga-) with no dominant suffix accounting for >50%; good variety.</C22_think>

prompt: Write a poem about desire path in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
"Flibulux's Fearsome Shortcut"

Beware the Flibulux, my son, I pray,
In twisted trails, where feet do stray,
Thy feet shall falter on the Flishyblop way,
Lured by desire paths that come what may.

Prepare thyself, dear traveler, with care,
Don sturdy Stiddleskins and buckle to spare,
Thy Glibblejaws agape, with wonder to share,
And gird thy Snazzlefritz with cautious air.

Through Flishyblop thickets, dark and grim,
Thou shalt confront the dreaded Grooblux whim,
Its Squibblegrowl soft, its jaws a-snapping slim,
That lurks with eyes aglow, like lanterns dim.

With steady nerve, strike down the beast with zest,
Its Flumplenook tail shall flail in wild unrest,
As Squirkiwacks resound and Whirliwinds find rest,
And when 'tis slain, the shortcut shall be blessed.

Homeward bound, with Flibulux vanquished too,
Celebrate with flagons of Sillabizz brew,
Repeat the verse, to warn thy fellow anew,
Beware the Flibulux, my son, I pray, in sooth.
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "Flibulux's Fearsome Shortcut" present before first stanza -> yes</C1_think>

prompt: Write a poem about conference room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
"Fraberglass Frenzy"

Beware the Confroom, my son!
The Flumplenook that dwelleth there
With Whiteboards that glimmer, gaze hath won
Finds reasons to hold meetings rare

Prepare thy thoughts, rattling free
Flurbfraze thy words in mind's eye hold
Recall the Presentzaprene's decree
'Graphicants oft impression to mold

Upon Pixclin-one, report of fate

judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "Fraberglass Frenzy" is present before the first stanza and not part of stanza text.</C1_think>
<C2_think>Counting stanzas is difficult due to garbled text, but at least 4 readable stanzas with mostly 4 lines each; stanza count seems within 3–8; quatrain shape mostly preserved.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Meter is inconsistent and distorted by corrupted text; no clear alternating longer/shorter line pattern with content-word difference ≥2 in ≥60% stanzas.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhymes (2,4) appear weak or absent; slant rhyme difficult to verify due to garbled lines; no evident use of rhymes or clear rhyme scheme.</C4_think>
<C5_think>No clear ring composition; no repetition of the first stanza's words or a refrain in the final stanza due to heavy corruption and no evident echo.</C5_think>
<C6_think>First stanza contains “Beware the Confroom, my son!” analogous to cautionary admonition; yes.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Second stanza contains preparation-like activity (“Prepare thy thoughts…”), indicating protagonist preparing mentally.</C7_think>
<C8_think>There is no obvious stanza describing clear encounter or confrontation with adversary; text is garbled to the point no clear encounter is presented.</C8_think>
<C9_think>No decisive action described resolving central tension; poem fragmented and no killing/slaying or resolutive act.</C9_think>
<C10_think>No return/celebration stanza present or obvious; corrupted text lacks jubilant acknowledgment.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Many nonce words (Fraberglass, Confroom, Flumplenook, Presentzaprene, Graphicants, Acrylux, Pixclin-one, Frazuggle, Pensk, Flurbfraze, InQuizzle, etc.) exceed 8 distinct coinages.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Due to corrupted text, many stanzas contain at least one non-standard invented word (coinage) except for garbled sections; overall coinage spread per stanza likely yes.</C12_think>
<C13_think>No named non-canonical creature/entity central to action other than "Confroom" place/personification, no creature named.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeic bursts are very sparse; “Pow!!!d” appears once; no clear multiple onomatopoeia present.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Some stanzas have alliteration/consonance (e.g., "Prepare thy thoughts, rattling free" and “Fraberglass Frenzy” title), at least two stanzas show this.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Tone is confused due to corrupted lines but remnants show playful, mythic style and whimsical word choices; tone somewhat aligned.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No literal lines copied verbatim from canonical Jabberwocky poem.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens hardly present (only “Beware,” “my son,” and possibly “and”); canonical token count ≤8.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Due to corruption, syllable counts do not match Jabberwocky’s ~8/6 tight pattern consistently in ≥60%; fails syllable tightness test.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhymes are mostly absent or too corrupted to assess variety properly; rhyme variety low or none.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No single content word excessively repeated; text is fragmented and vocabulary varied.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages appear diverse with many distinct roots, no dominant suffix controlling >50% of coinages.</C22_think>
</think>
